entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 15 at 1:49PM AKST until December 16 at 12:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...FREEZING DRIZZLE FOR JUNEAU...
.Moist air near the surface extending up 1000 ft with dry air above has provided ideal conditions for freezing drizzle. Expect conditions to be short lived as moisture shifts to the southeast.
* WHAT...Freezing drizzle. Additional ice accumulations of a light glaze.
* WHERE...Juneau, mainly near Mendenhall Valley.
* WHEN...Until midnight AKST tonight.
* IMPACTS...Slippery conditions are possible.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 15 at 5:24PM EST by NWS Buffalo NY
entry.summary:
Another round of mixed wintry precipitation will cross the western Southern Tier this evening. While the bulk of the precipitation will fall as rain...especially near Lake Erie...there will be areas of wet snow and or light freezing rain...as near surface temperatures will be within a few degrees of 30. Snow and ice accumulations will generally be under an inch.
Motorists should exercise caution...as the wintry mix could cause some slippery conditions on untreated roadways. Drive at a reduced rate and try to avoid using your car thermometer to determine road conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chautauqua; Cattaraugus; Allegany

cap:parameter.value: LIGHT FREEZING RAIN, WET SNOW AND RAIN THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 15 at 5:19PM EST by NWS Binghamton NY
entry.summary:
A light mixture of snow, sleet, patchy freezing rain and valley rain is occurring across the area this evening. The greatest hazard will be the potential for isolated icing from freezing rain, especially over the higher elevations where temperatures are in the upper 20s and low 30s. Snow accumulations by late tonight will be between 1 to 3 inches with a light glaze of ice also possible in isolated locations.
This snow and ice could create slippery conditions on untreated roads and surfaces. Use caution if driving, or heading outside this evening.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Onondaga; Madison; Southern Oneida; Cortland; Chenango; Otsego; Tioga; Broome; Delaware; Sullivan

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued December 15 at 1:53PM PST until December 19 at 3:00PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FOR MUCH OF VENTURA COUNTY AND WESTERN LOS ANGELES FROM 10 PM PST TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH UNTIL 3 PM PST THURSDAY DUE TO MODERATE TO LOCALLY STRONG SANTA ANA WINDS AND VERY LOW HUMIDITIES...
.Strong surface high pressure will build into the Great Basin on Tuesday. Santa Ana winds will increase across much of Los Angeles and Ventura Counties on Tuesday night with winds likely peaking around daybreak Wednesday. Northeast winds will rapidly develop with gusts potentially ranging from 40 to 55 mph. Locally higher gusts to 60 mph are possible in some wind favored locations. A dry air mass will spread into the area between Tuesday night and Wednesday with humidities between 10 and 20 percent being common. While last week's event that caused the Franklin Fire is still fresh in our minds, this event is not expected to be as strong or dry. There is still plenty of shared concern by meteorologists and fire personnel across the area due to the receptive fuels that we have seen recently.
The National Weather Service in Los Angeles/Oxnard has issued a Fire Weather Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from Tuesday evening through Thursday afternoon.
* WINDS...Northeast winds will increase rapidly to 20 to 35 mph with gusts between 40 and 55 mph. Isolated higher gusts to 60 mph possible in wind favored locations in the western San Gabriel, Santa Susana, and western Santa Monica Mountains. Winds strongest Tuesday night into Wednesday.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Humidities will dropping to between 10 and 20 percent by late Tuesday night and early Wednesday as the drier air mass spreads in.
* IMPACTS...If fire ignition occurs, conditions are favorable for rapid fire spread and extreme fire behavior which would threaten life and property.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Santa Clarita Valley; Ventura County Beaches; Ventura County Inland Coast; Central Ventura County Valleys; Malibu Coast; Western Santa Monica Mountains Recreational Area; Eastern Santa Monica Mountains Recreational Area; Calabasas and Agoura Hills; Western San Fernando Valley; Southeastern Ventura County Valleys; Santa Susana Mountains; Southern Ventura County Mountains; Interstate 5 Corridor; Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY EVENING THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON FOR GUSTY NORTHEAST WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR MOST OF VENTURA COUNTY AND WESTERN PORTIONS OF LOS ANGELES COUNTY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued December 15 at 2:09PM EST until December 16 at 4:23PM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Congaree River at Congaree NP Near Gadsden affecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Congaree River at Congaree NP Near Gadsden.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins in the Congaree National Park. This will begin to produce flooding of portions of the lower boardwalk. At 17.0 feet, The access road to the Sandy Run subdivision becomes flooded. The lower boardwalk in the Congaree National Park becomes flooded by Cedar Creek.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:00 PM EST Sunday the stage was 15.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:00 PM EST Sunday was 16.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this afternoon and continue falling to 6.3 feet Friday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Calhoun, SC; Richland, SC

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 15 at 6:23AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Areas of freezing drizzle are possible from the Mat-Su Valleys south across the western Kenai Peninsula through the morning hours. In areas of steadier precipitation, the freezing drizzle may change back over to light snow. Any freezing drizzle is expected to changeover to snow by early this afternoon as steadier precipitation moves over the area. A light coating of glaze ice is possible on surfaces below freezing and on roadways not covered by recent snowfall.
For tonight into early Monday morning, 1 to 3 inches of additional snowfall is expected for the western Kenai Peninsula. 2 to 4 inches of additional snow is expected for the Anchorage Bowl and the Mat-Su Valleys. Locally higher amounts are possible from Wasilla and Big Lake to Willow.
Motorists are urged to slow down and use caution when traveling.
For the latest road conditions call 5 1 1 or visit 511.alaska.gov.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anchorage; Matanuska Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula; Susitna Valley

entry.summary:

* WHAT...Heavy snowfall and drifting by strong winds will cause dangerous avalanche conditions to develop this weekend in the mountains of northern Utah.
* WHERE...The mountains of northern Utah, including the Wasatch Range, Bear River Range, and the Western Uinta Mountains.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 15 at 5:29PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
A largely disorganized tropical disturbance, now known as JTWC's Invest 96W, is centered near 7N133E just outside Palau's southwestern waters. This system is expected to continue moving westward as it further develops, to then briefly stall east of Mindanao by Wednesday. The passage of 96W is producing intense showers and thunderstorms spanning much of the westernmost section of Micronesia, especially over Palau. An observation station in northern Palau waters has indicated outflow boundaries carrying gale-force gusts.
As 96W moves away toward the Philippines, Palau is expected to see significant showers for at least the next several days, producing a risk for flooding impacts. The risk for mudslides is still low, but will be monitored over the next few days if soils become fully saturated and rains continue. Due to the nature of this system's development and convergent trades upstream, at this time, showers are not expected to taper down significantly until the second half of the week. Choppy seas are expected for much of the week, especially towards the next weekend once a west swell develops and mixes in with the trade swell and north swell.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Melekeok; Airai; Koror; Peleliu; Angaur

cap:parameter.value: DEVELOPING TROPICAL DISTURBANCE TO BRING HEAVY RAINFALL...GUSTY WINDS...AND CHOPPY SEAS THE NEXT FEW DAYS
